info.document:
Find out what is making news in the Highlands.

View More Local BusinessList Your Business Here

That's a wrap for today. Don't forget to join us again on tomorrow from 7.00AM.

Being a mum can be hard work.

►As Book Week 2017 activities wrap up this week, we're reflecting on all of the colourful and character-filled parades.

Do you have a photo to share? Email it to emily.bennett@fairfaxmedia.com.au and we'll include it in our gallery.

►Country music is in Hilary Colwell's blood.

She has toured with Australian country music legend Slim Dusty and amassed a collection of over 3000 records.

Now, after three decades at the helm, the Highlands FM presenter - known as Billie Jo Cheers to avid listeners - is stepping down.

►The presence and power of nature is potent in the latest exhibition to go on display at Bowral Art Gallery.

Old friends Kerrie Leishman, Penelope McManus and Penny Simons have come together to showcase their latest individual collections of artwork.

Each collection explores the women's relationship with their environment.

►Young people in the Highlands are being given the opportunity to develop and voice their best ideas and innovations.

Young Change Agents (YCA) is a free event held at Kazcare from September 26 to 28 that aims to identify and foster the next big social entrepreneurial ideas among Highlands youth.

The two and a half day "Shark Tank" style workshop is designed to "help our youth see social problems as innovations".

►Local sports clubs are being invited to apply for grants of up to $20,000, with Member for Goulburn Pru Goward saying the focus this year is encouraging more talented girls and young women into sport programs.

"Around half of all Australian boys are active through a sports club during their childhood compared with just 33 per cent of girls, and the participation rate for girls drops sharply after girls turn 12," Ms Goward said. More here.

►

A Commonwealth statistician once admitted to me that "economies don't swing, statisticians do".

It was a warning to not place too much emphasis on any one data point, but to try to ascertain trends over time.

This week saw the release of the economic growth numbers for the June quarter of this year, and for the financial year 2016-17. GDP grew by 0.8 percent in the June quarter, and by 1.8 percent over the financial year.

While this was a "much of a muchness" result, some have seized on it as evidence that our economy is strengthening, and claim that it is likely to continue to do so. John Hewson shares his views here.

TRAFFIC: All roads are clear in the Southern Highlands today. Drive safely and enjoy the journey.

TRAINS: Commuters can expect a good service on the Southern Highlands today.

WEATHER: A partly cloudy day witha slight chance of a shower during the day, winds W 20 to 30 km/h increasing to 30 to 40 km/h in the morningand a daytime maximum temperature of 12 can be expected in the Highlands today.

Here's a look at what the local weather is doing right now.

Good morning and welcome to the Southern Highlands Rise and Shine. Here's a wrap of what has been grabbing the interests Highlanders.

Weather, road conditions, breaking news, we will have it all - and we'd love to have your help! If there's anything happening in your part of the world, drop us a line! Email jackie.meyers@fairfaxmedia.com.au
